citations.narrative:
* There are Two Yorkshire Terrier, Two Morkie, One King Charles, One Maltase and Two Affenpinscher dogs that have
no official identification on them at time of inspection.
* Official identification is needed to ensure that each animal s identity can be known with certainty which helps to facilitate
the inspection process. The licensee is using microchips as the official identification. The licensee must ensure that all live
dogs on the premise shall be identified by an official tag, a distinctive and legible tattoo marking or microchip system that
is acceptable to and approved by the Administrator or a microchip chip number.

* There were Two Australian Shepherd, Two Yorkshire Terrier, One King Charles, Three Affenpinscher, Two Morkie, One
Shih Tzu, One Bichon, One Cavachon and Five Maltase dogs that were not listed on the inventory records being used by
the licensee.
* In addition, the licensee stated that she sent 43 puppies to rescue (on two different occasions). The licensee also does
not have all required disposition information (APHIS 7006) for these dogs. The following information was missing on the
disposition records on the 43 puppies.
1) Name and address of the person whom the puppies were given to and the license number of the person if he or she is
licensed.
2) Dates the puppies were disposed of.
3) Official USDA tag number or tattoo assigned to the puppies.
4) The species and breed or type of puppies.
5) Sex of the puppies.
6) Date of birth.
7) Color and any distinctive markings.
When the dog numbers currently at the facility do not match it makes the records incomplete. Complete and accurate
records are needed to ensure each animal’s identity can be known with certainty, track the movement of animals and to
facilitate the inspection process. The licensee must maintain complete and accurate records of all animals at all times at
their facility. The licensee must make, keep, and maintain records or forms which fully and correctly disclose the full and
correct information required concerning each dog or cat purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held, or otherwise in his
or her possession or under his or her control, or which is transported, euthanized, sold, or otherwise disposed of by that
dealer or exhibitor.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
Additional Inspectors:
KATHRYN VERNON, ANIMAL CARE INSPECTOR n

narrative:
2.50(a)(1)  Repeat
   
Time and method of identification. 
* There are Two Yorkshire Terrier, Two Morkie, One King Charles, One Maltase and Two Affenpinscher dogs that have

* Official identification is needed to ensure that each animal s identity can be known with certainty which helps to facilitate 
the inspection process. The licensee is using microchips as the official identification. The licensee must ensure that all live 
dogs on the premise shall be identified by an official tag, a distinctive and legible tattoo marking or microchip system that 
is acceptable to and approved by the Administrator or a microchip chip number. 
2.75(a)(1)  Repeat
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
* There were Two Australian Shepherd, Two Yorkshire Terrier, One King Charles, Three Affenpinscher, Two Morkie, One 
Shih Tzu, One Bichon, One Cavachon and Five Maltase dogs that were not listed on the inventory records being used by 
the licensee.  
* In addition, the licensee stated that she sent 43 puppies to rescue (on two different occasions). The licensee also does 
not have all required disposition information (APHIS 7006) for these dogs. The following information was missing on the 
disposition records on the 43 puppies.  
1) Name and address of the person whom the puppies were given to and the license number of the person if he or she is 
licensed.  
2) Dates the puppies were disposed of. 
3) Official USDA tag number or tattoo assigned to the puppies. 
4) The species and breed or type of puppies. 
5) Sex of the puppies. 
6) Date of birth. 
7) Color and any distinctive markings. 
When the dog numbers currently at the facility do not match it makes the records incomplete. Complete and accurate 
records are needed to ensure each animal’s identity can be known with certainty, track the movement of animals and to 
facilitate the inspection process. The licensee must maintain complete and accurate records of all animals at all times at 
their facility. The licensee must make, keep, and maintain records or forms which fully and correctly disclose the full and 
correct information required concerning each dog or cat purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held, or otherwise in his

or her possession or under his or her control, or which is transported, euthanized, sold, or otherwise disposed of by that 
dealer or exhibitor. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
KATHRYN VERNON, ANIMAL CARE INSPECTOR n
